statement: Monthly rent is considered a fixed expense in a budget.
A budget helps track income and expenses to manage money effectively.
According to the 50/30/20 budgeting rule, 50% of your income should go toward savings and debt repayment.
Discretionary expenses are essential costs like rent and utilities.
The envelope method involves assigning specific cash amounts for each spending category.
Zero-based budgeting leaves some income unassigned to encourage flexibility.
An emergency fund is primarily used for planned purchases like vacations.
A savings account is designed to store money and earn interest over time.
Compounding allows you to earn interest on both your initial deposit and the interest you’ve already earned.
A certificate of deposit (CD) allows unlimited withdrawals without penalty.
High-yield savings accounts typically offer higher interest rates than traditional savings accounts.
Inflation increases the purchasing power of your savings over time.
Checking accounts are primarily used for daily transactions.
An ATM allows cash withdrawals and deposits using a debit card.
FDIC insurance protects your investment portfolio from stock market losses.
Online banks often provide higher interest rates due to lower overhead costs.
The routing number identifies your specific account at a bank.
The Truth in Savings Act requires banks to disclose fees and interest rates clearly to consumers.
A credit card allows you to borrow money up to a set limit for purchases.
Paying only the minimum balance on your credit card helps you avoid all interest charges.
Your payment history has the greatest impact on your FICO credit score.
A hard inquiry can temporarily lower your credit score.
A higher Credit Utilization Ratio can help increase your credit score.
Closing an old credit card always improves your credit score.
A fixed-rate loan has an interest rate that can change over time.
Borrowing money means you are taking on debt that must be repaid with interest.
The debt snowball method focuses on paying off the smallest balance first.
A loan’s annual percentage rate (APR) includes both interest and fees.
The Avalanche Method focuses on paying off debts with the highest interest rate first.
Defaulting on a loan will not affect your credit score if you repay it later.
Diversification reduces investment risk by spreading money across different asset types.
Stocks represent ownership in a company.
A bond represents a loan you give to a company or government.
Mutual funds allow investors to pool money for diversified investing.
Beta measures how often a company pays dividends to its shareholders.
The Rule of 72 helps estimate how long it takes for money to double at a given interest rate.
An employer’s matching contribution to a 401(k) plan is optional and depends on employee participation.
A 401(k) is a retirement savings plan offered by employers.
Withdrawals from a Traditional IRA are tax-free during retirement.
Roth IRA contributions are made with after-tax dollars.
You can withdraw from your 401(k) at any time without penalties or taxes.
Compound growth allows retirement savings to increase exponentially over time.
Taxes are payments individuals and businesses make to the government.
Sales tax is applied to income earned during the year.
A tax credit directly reduces the amount of tax you owe.
Tax deductions reduce your taxable income.
If you are in the 24% tax bracket, your entire income is taxed at 24%.
A progressive tax system means higher income is taxed at higher rates.
A deductible is the amount you pay before your insurance begins to cover costs.
Health insurance helps cover medical expenses.
The premium is the amount you pay regularly to keep your insurance active.
Liability insurance covers damages you cause to others or their property.
Whole life insurance covers you for a specific period and does not build cash value.
An insurance policy’s coverage limit is the maximum amount the insurer will pay for a claim.
Identity theft occurs when someone uses your personal information without permission.
If a deal sounds too good to be true, it’s usually safe to trust.
Phishing scams use fake emails or messages to trick people into revealing personal information.
Skimming devices are used to steal credit card information during legitimate transactions.
A Ponzi scheme uses money from new investors to pay earlier investors instead of generating real profit.
Insider trading is a legal way for executives to profit from confidential company information.
